title: WCAS AF_AM_ST 212-2-1 Introduction to African American History: Emancipation to Civil Rights Movement

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to a broad overview of African American history from Emancipation to the present. In this class, we will examine African Americans' pursuit of freedom and justice as defined in different eras and their attempts at forging a cultural identity within the United States and across the African diaspora. Key themes for this course will include the impact of national and international politics on black communities, the role of intersecting identity categories in complicating the notion of a single "black experience," and the efficacy of different tools and tactics for political and personal expression. By the end of this quarter, students will understand some of the important concepts and movements that shaped the last 150 years of African American history.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Group assignment: 10% of final grade
(2) Three-page papers: 20% each
Midterm exam: 25%
Final exam: 25%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The required texts for the course are:
W.E.B. Du Bois, The Souls of Black Folk
James Baldwin, The Fire Next Time
Audre Lorde, Sister Outsider: Essays and Speeches
Ta-nehisi Coates, Between the World and Me

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
We will also be reading excerpts from the following:
Hannah Rosen, Terror in the Heart of Freedom: Citizenship, Sexual Violence, and the Meaning of Race in the Post-emancipation South
Brent Hayes Edwards, The Practice of Diaspora: Literature, Translation, and the Rise of Black Internationalism
Christopher Reed, The Depression Comes to South Side: Protest and Politics in the Black Metropolis, 1930-1933
Bill V. Mullen, Popular Fronts: Chicago and African-American Cultural Products, 1935-1946
Penny M. Von Eschen, Race Against Empire: Black Americans and Anticolonialism, 1937-1957
Charles M. Payne, I've Got the Light of Freedom: The Organizing Tradition and the Mississippi Freedom Struggle
John D'Emilio, Lost Prophet: The Life and Times of Bayard Rustin
Barbara Ransby, Ella Baker and the Black Freedom Movement: A Radical Democratic Vision
Joseph Peniel, Waiting ?Til the Midnight Hour: A Narrative History of Black Power in America
Thomas Sugrue, Origins of the Urban Crisis: Race and Inequality in Postwar Detroit
Michelle Alexander, The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness
